awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Creation of Active Granular Materials and Study of Emergent Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
Imagine on a hike that on command your walking stick becomes a chair, and should you fall and break your arm, the chair becomes a splint. Such taskable "super-materials" are the stuﬀ of science fiction and will require drastic advances in material science. Such materials will depend not only on the properties of constituent elements, but also the emergent dynamics governing them. Research in programmable matter and swarm robotics is increasingly popular, but has largely been in the domain of engineers and computer scientists. The bulk of active matter studies in physics have been conducted theoretically, and often fails to adequately capture real-world physical interactions between elements which may critically influence the overall behavior. The proposed work will focus on a simple and accessible framework combining experiments, simulations, and theory via active granular materials (entangled robots), and explore distributed control schemes by which such materials can sense, locomote, and change properties and morphologies both locally and globally. 

Technical Abstract:
Combining insights from swarm robotics and experimental and soft matter physics, this project will focus on the physics principles by which entangled robot swarms, or "active granular matter", can alter local mechanical states to produce global emergent behaviors; i.e. where the physical interactions dominate explicit coordination between robots. While active matter physics is a vibrant area of research, there are few well-controlled experimental systems in which theoretical advances can be tested in controlled situations, where parameters like material shape, density, and activity can be rapidly varied, and even fewer that incorporate the role of sensing and feedback into the dynamics. Therefore, to enable discovery of new dynamics in dense soft matter physics this project involves 1) a scalable, granular robotics platform with 100+ individuals; 2) theoretical and experimental tools for analysis and validation, such as hopper flows, shear cells, and numerical multi-physics simulations; and 3) distributed algorithms for producing and transitioning between emergent behaviors and material properties such as motion, morphology, porosity, and yield strength.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Smart and programmable matter can be created from conglomerates of active robotic modules which can interact mechanically to achieve useful material-wide behaviors. While smart matter has many potential applications, creating and studying it difficult. Pure simulation studies often fail to capture details of physical interactions, and robotic platforms often lack capability and numbers to study capable conglomerates.  Through this funding we have introduced a new robotic platform that can support algorithmic development for taskable modular robots and studies of active matter. Specifically, inspired by rafts of fire ants, our design represents an iteration of robots capable of entangling to various degrees by periodically oscillating two appendages. Entanglement can be beneficial over discrete connections between modules because it 1) does not require precise module-module alignment; 2) does not require expensive, heavy, and bulky coupling mechanisms; and 3) although it cannot produce particular formations, it does enable modules to couple loosely to generate materials and conglomerates with different shapes and rheological and structural properties like viscosity, yield stress, and packing density, or even the ability to produce locomotion through periodic contractions throughout the material.

Our new design is inexpensive, can be fabricated quickly, requires little know-how to deploy and operate, and is meant to support large-scale deployment and operation in research labs across physics, biology, and robotics disciplines. The robots can communicate and sense their surroundings optically, acoustically, and mechanically. Most importantly their aspect ratio and strength supports dense entanglement, meaning that we can now produce amorphous ‘blobs’ of robots that can actively change their degree of entanglement. The next exiting venture is to design algorithms around this new type of robotic system that relies on statistical trends in behavior, rather than exact control of formation and topology.  

Beyond this new platform, the funding led to several new ideas for coordination techniques and robotic platforms based on oscillators. First, we demonstrated new robotic matter composed of soft, magnetically-coupled robots, capable of doubling their circumference, while sensing strain on their perimeter. Beyond the ability for individual modules to change their size and stiffness, fabric-like surfaces composed of many of these may be able to contort into pre-specified patterns, similar to epithelial tissues, or respond intelligently to environmental perturbations, e.g. stiffening up locally upon sudden impact. Second, we introduced a new model for chiral swarmalators – oscillating particles that move in a nominally circular trajectory capable of synchronizing temporally and spatially with others. While highly abstracted, we found that when many of these swarmalators interact, they can reproduce complex emergent phenomena in both natural and engineered systems, from vortex patterns in sperm cells and microrobots, to mosh pit dynamics. As such, the model may be used to support future studies and insights on swarm behavior across biology, active matter, and robotics.  Finally, we designed new robots with oscillating tails capable of interacting with a granular environment autonomously, i.e. by creating mounds, digging indents, and transporting granules. While current demonstrations are limited to simple 2D operation, these minimalistic mechanisms show promising potential for autonomous construction of access structures such as ramps and plateaus which are passable by less mobile personnel or other machinery.

This funding supported two graduate students, several undergraduates and Master of Engineering projects over 3 years; resulting work was presented in a number of journals, conferences, workshops, and academic seminars, as well as several high school outreach events.
